qas.question: What term is used to test functionality of the software accordingly with the application requirements?
What are the test cases built around?
When building test cases which of the two methods used is more common over the other?

plausible_answers.text: the functionality of software according to the applicable requirements.

qas.question: What does specialization-based testing aim to test?
Test cases are built around specializations and what else?
Out of the two methods of building test cases, non-functional and unfunctional, which is more common?
What descriptions of the firmware are used in test cases?

context: <a0_0>Specification-based testing<a0_0/> aims to test <b3_0>the functionality of software according to the applicable requirements.<b3_0/> This level of testing usually requires thorough test cases to be provided to the tester, who then can simply verify that for a given input, the output value (or behavior), either "is" or "is not" the same as the expected value specified in the test case. Test cases are built around <a1_0>specifications and <b4_0>requirements<b4_0/><a1_0/>, i.e., what the application is supposed to do. It uses external descriptions of the software, including <b6_0>specifications, requirements, and designs<b6_0/> to derive test cases. These tests can be functional or non-functional, though usually <a2_0><b5_0>functional<b5_0/><a2_0/>.
